newsitem.title: USA: Smith Barney sees Wall St boom well into 1997.
newsitem.headline: Smith Barney sees Wall St boom well into 1997.

text.p: Wall Street's boom is likely to continue well into 1997, with few clouds to mar its performance, Smith Barney analysts said on Tuesday.
"Our feeling is that the major bull markets both in stocks and bonds still have a way to run," Alan Shaw, manager of Smith Barney's technical research team, told reporters.
He and other analysts said the market was being driven by low interest rates and high liquidity exemplified by money pouring into mutual funds, a trend unlikely to change soon.
They forecast an increase in 1997 gross domestic product between two and 2.5 percent and a modest increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve in the first part of next year.
"We still feel the next move by the Fed will be to higher interest rates," said Mitchell Held, the firm's chief economist.

He said unemployment could dip to below five percent from the present 5.2 percent and recent data showed the fastest level of income growth was among the lowest 20 percent of American workers, both signs for optimism.
But Signs of trouble include a sharp rise in consumer debt, which in turn could slow down consumer spending, and slow growth overseas that could hamper U.S. exports, Held said.
Keith Mullins, emerging growth stock strategist, forecast the Standard and Poors 500 stocks would only see one percent profit growth next year over 1996.
His recommended stocks included Staples Inc, Dollar Tree Stores Inc, EMC Corp, Informix Corp, HBO & Co, Paychex Inc and La Quinta Inns Inc.
